titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the 7th Regiment Records
1767-1983 (bulk, 1830-1947)
MS 556
titlestmt.author: Maurita Baldock, Richard Fraser, Melissa Haley, Jan Hilley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-02-28 14:18:04 -0500.

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: United States. Army. New York Infantry Regiment, 7th (Militia) (1806-1922)

did.abstract:
This collection documents the history and administration of the 7th Regiment of New York. The bulk of the material pertains to regimental management, organization, and events, rather than its participation in combat and other military activities. Items include orders, correspondence, financial and legal records, reports, by-laws, enlistment records, and rosters from 7th Regiment headquarters and companies. Also included is material relating to the regiment's armories (especially the Park Ave. and 66th St. location), veterans' organizations, music, athletic clubs, recreational activities, and entertainment. The collection contains numerous scrapbooks, visual materials, publications, artifacts, and ephemera.
Selections from the 7th Regiment Records are digitized and available in the Shelby White and Leon Levy Digital Library.
Portions of the collection relating to the Civil War are available to on-site researchers and to users affiliated with subscribing institutions via EBSCOhost.
did.physloc: Materials in this collection may be stored offsite. For more information on making arrangements to consult them, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.
did.langmaterial: The documents in this collection are in English.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Materials in this collection may be stored offsite. For more information on making arrangements to consult them, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donation by the 7th Regiment, 1948. Subsequent donations include 1961, 1964, 1968, 1972, 1977.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Selections from the 7th Regiment Records are digitized and available in the Shelby White and Leon Levy Digital Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
The 7th Regiment Records are organized in sixteen series:
Series I: Headquarters, 1767-1970
Series II: Companies, 1806-1949
Series III: Depot (Home) Battalion/Aqueduct Service, 1916-1929
Series IV: Francis D. Landon, 1908-1918
Series V: Robert M. Lester, 1942-1951
Series VI: Armory, 1860-1888
Series VII: Histories, 1831-1956
Series VIII: Scrapbooks, 1852-1946
Series IX: Ephemera, 1820-1976
Series X: Music, 1862-1952
Series XI: Recreational Activities, 1873-1950
Series XII: Library, 1860-1940
Series XIII: Publications, 1811-1976
Series XIV: Visual Materials, 1806-1983
Series XV: Maps, 1912-1948
Series XVI: Artifacts, 1806-1961

eventgrp.event: Organized in New York, in response to troubles with the British Navy, as four companies (A,B,C,D) of Artillery, assigned to the Battalion of Artillery, First Brigade.
Reorganized as 2d (Infantry) Battalion, 3d Regiment of Artillery, New York State Militia.
Redesignated 2d Battalion, 11th Regiment of Artillery, N.Y.S.M.
Active duty in New York harbor forts.

Adoption of name National Guards, in honor of Marquis de Lafayette (changed to National Guard in 1832).
Adoption of gray uniforms.
Declaration of intention to become a regiment.
Companies E,F,G, and H are added.
Reorganized and redesignated as 27th Regiment of Artillery, N.Y.S.M.
Co. I is formed of cavalry, designated "First Troop, National Guard."

event.title: Redesignated 7th Regiment of Infantry (National Guard), N.Y.S.M.

eventgrp.event: 7th Regiment suppresses Astor Place riot, killing 30.
7th Regiment Band is organized.
Engineers Corps is organized, titled Co. K in 1860.
The 7th quells two riots, one involving the Dead Rabbits and the Bowery Boys.
Mustered into federal service.
Mustered into federal service in Baltimore.
New York State Militia redesignated New York National Guard.
Mustered into federal service in Baltimore and Frederick, MD. Regiment called to New York for suppression of Draft Riots in July.
The 7th serves riot duty during Orange Riots.
Rifle Club is formed, regiment secures Creedmoor rifle range on Long Island.
7th Regiment Armory opens on Park Avenue and 66th Street.
Camp Smith, near Peekskill, N.Y., first used for field training.

Regiment on duty during Brooklyn street car strike.
Hospital Corps/ Medical Detachment is formed.
Regiment called to guard duty during Croton Reservoir labor trouble.
Rifle matches with Queen's Westminsters.
Howitzer Company formed from members of Cos. F,I, and K.
Company L is formed.
7th participates in Army-National Guard maneuvers in Mass. and Conn.
Supply/Service Company is formed.
7th mustered into federal service to guard the Mexican Border. Stationed at McAllen, TX.
Drafted into federal service.

event.title: Redesignated 107th Infantry and assigned to the 27th Division.

eventgrp.event: 7th Infantry, New York Guard serves as Depot (Home) Battalion.
27th Division is transferred to the British 4th Army. 107th Infantry engages in battles in Belgium and France; participates in assault on Hindenburg Line.
107th Infantry demobilized at Camp Upton, N.Y.
Consolidates with 7th Infantry, N.Y.G. and reorganized and federalized as 107th Infantry.
7th Regiment, N.Y. (State) Guard formed.
207th C.A.A.A. departs for Camp Stewart, Ga. 7th Regiment N.Y.G. occupies Armory.
207th C.A.A.A. assigned to duty at Newport, R.I.

Regiment broken up, reorganized and redesignated:
HQ and HQ Battery becomes HQ and HQ Battery 207th Anti-Aircraft Artillery Group
1st Battalion becomes 771st Anti-Aircraft Artillery Gun Battalion
2d Battalion becomes 7th Anti-Aircraft Artillery Automatic Weapons Battalion
3d Battalion becomes 247th Anti-Aircraft Artillery Searchlight Battalion.

207th ships to England, takes part in Normandy invasion. Moves into France, Luxembourg, and Germany.
7th A.A.A. Battalion serves in Pacific, on Guam, Leyte, and in the Ryukyus.
771st A.A.A. Battalion serves in Pacific at Oahu, Eniwetok, Ulithi, and Guam.
247th A.A.A. remains in U.S.
Consolidated, reorganized and recognized as 107th Infantry, assigned to 107th Regimental Combat Team, with HQ in New York.
Relieved from 107th Regimental Combat Team, assigned to 42d Infantry Division.
Relieved from 42d Infantry Division, reorganized as 107th Infantry, parent regiment under the Combat Arms Regimental System.
Creation of 107th Support Group.
Marshall Lefferts
Emmons Clark
Daniel Appleton

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as the 7th Regiment Records, MS 556, The New-York Historical Society.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The N-YHS Library's holdings include nearly 4,000 titles from the 7th Regiment Military Library, as well as numerous other items by or about the 7th Regiment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection documents the history and administration of the 7th Regiment of New York. The bulk of the material pertains to regimental management, organization, and events, rather than its participation in combat and other military activities. Items include orders, correspondence, financial and legal records, reports, by-laws, enlistment records, and rosters from 7th Regiment headquarters and companies. Also included is material relating to the regiment's armories (especially the Park Ave. and 66th St. location), veterans' organizations, music, athletic clubs, recreational activities, and entertainment. The collection contains numerous scrapbooks, visual materials, publications, artifacts, and ephemera.

Material documenting the regiment's military service includes reports and rosters from the Depot (Home) Battalion, 7th Infantry who defended the Pleasantville, NY aqueduct in 1917. Items relating to World War I can be found in Company F's files in Series II, including orders, memos, bulletins, and schedules. World War I Ephemera in Series IX contains instructional, promotional and recruitment material. In addition, numerous WWI posters are located in Visual Materials. The collection also contains correspondence, personnel, publications, clippings, visual materials, and a scrapbook pertaining to the 7th Regiment's service on the Mexican border, while stationed at McAllen, Texas in 1916.

Other military documentation includes a brief account of the regiment's participation in quelling the Astor Place Riots, scrapbooks relating to 1909 and 1912 war game maneuvers, and visual materials depicting camp life. Material on military training and instruction can be found in the headquarters and Francis Landon series. Civil War material includes enrollment lists found in Personnel (Series I), a number of photographs and photo albums in Visual Materials (Series XIV), and two diaries in Histories (Series VII): an anonymous diary describing training at Camp Scott on Staten Island in 1860, and a copy of Alexander Shaler's diary as a prisoner of war in 1864. There is little or no material regarding the 7th Regiment's participation in suppressing the 1863 Draft Riots.

Throughout its history, the 7th Regiment's military designation changed several times (see historical note). Folder titles reflect the various identities of the regiment, when applicable. The arrangement of the 7th Regiment Records partially follows military entities, particularly headquarters and company material. Items from military levels higher than regiment, such as division or brigade, can be found in the headquarters series.
Additional descriptive notes are included at the Series level.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Taking images of documents from the library collections for reference purposes by using hand-held cameras and in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff.

Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhistory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.

Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than the New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: https://www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions

controlaccess.corpname: United States. Army. New York Infantry Regiment, 7th (Militia) (1806-1922)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Headquarters series consists of materials relating to the organization and management of the regiment as a whole. The series is divided into types of material including orders, correspondence and letterbooks, financial material, legal material, training material, and minutes and reports. The series also includes material on the Committees and Board of Officers, personnel information, and material from Veterans organizations of the 7th Regiment.

The Headquarters series contains some materials from military rankings higher than the regiment level. These include materials from the New York State Guard, as well as divisions, and brigades. These can be found within the subseries of types of material such as orders, correspondence, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The orders are organized by recipient. The regimental orders consist of special, training, parade, post, and regular orders and are organized chronologically. Orders to the New York State Guard and different divisions, brigades, and battalions are also in this series, placed after the regimental orders. In the bound orders, many circulars are also included. Note that orders directed to companies are with the companies series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The regimental correspondence is arranged chronologically. It is mostly incoming correspondence to the regiment, but some copies and carbon copies of outgoing correspondence are included. Some letters to the Board of Officers and correspondence among soldiers and officials of the 7th Regiment are also included. Most of the correspondence documents routine matters such as invitations to dinners and events, resignations, elections of officers, parades, uniforms, and the use of the armory. Events such as the Astor Place Riots, the Draft Riots, the Civil War, and World War I are not represented in the correspondence. However, some letters from 1916 from McAllen, Texas detail the camp conditions and the attitude of the men while guarding the Mexican Border.

The letterbooks contain the correspondence of Colonel Appleton and Colonel Clark which detail the administrative management of the regiment. The letterbook of Philip Rhinelander contains correspondence regarding his collecting of Civil War relics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of formal communication within the 7th Regiment that is not orders. This includes memos, circulars, and other notices to members. It also includes internal communications in the division of militia affairs of the war department, brigades, and the New York Guard.

did.unittitle: Eleventh Regiment of the New York State Artillery- Memoranda
7th Regiment New York Guard (State Guard)- Memoranda
War Department, Division of Militia Affairs- Circular
National Guard State of New York- Circulars
Department of Rifle Practice, State of New York- 1875-1878
Inspector General's Department, State of New York- Circulars
Subseries 4: Board of Officers and Committees, 1833-1949

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains material produced by the regiment's Board of Officers and its various committees. The Board of Officers material includes by-laws, resolutions, meeting minutes, minute books, and reports of the officers. The committee material is reports from various committees to the Board of Officers. The main committees of the regiment include the Armory Committee, the Committee on the Awards of the Cross of Honor, the Library and Arts Committee, and the General Committee on the New Armory. The regiment had other special committees that met for a short duration to complete a special project, such as a committee on an upcoming ball. These special committees are together in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes regimental rosters, rolls, returns, enrollment lists and certificates, and attendance reports. Much of the loose material relates to the Civil War, especially printed lists (booklets, newspapers and posters) of New York City recruits and draftees. Also included in this subseries are lists of 7th Regiment war dead from the First and Second World Wars and the Korean War. Bound volumes in this subseries are muster rolls, roll books, and rosters.
For rosters of individual 7th Regiment companies, see Series II (especially Bound Volumes), and the Veterans of the 7th Regiment files in this series, Subseries 10.

Certificates, Rolls
Enlistment and appointment certificates. Includes several certificates for William H. Kipp (1857-1908). Also rolls for 11th Reg. (1806-1820), Battery F (1940) and Exempt Members (1860-1863, 1910-1914).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The financial material contains annual reports, account books, material related to pay and insurance, and a large number of bills and receipts. For further financial information see the Treasurer's Reports in the Board of Officers subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The legal material of the 7th Regiment consists mainly of court martials but also includes wills, testimonies, transcripts of court proceeding, acts, and affidavits. There are some court martials from the Headquarters of the Army and the First Brigade, New York State Artillery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains manuals, pamphlets, handouts, exercises, and notes related to specific regimental training. Many of the materials are related to controlling riots.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The report books are records of attendance of members of each company present at drills, parades, or practices.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries primarily contains material for various veterans associations including Veterans of the 7th Regiment, Society of the War Veterans, and Veterans of the National Guard. The bulk of the Veterans of the 7th Regiment material is files from the 1940s containing correspondence and company rosters. Correspondence consists mostly of letters from veterans to William B. Miles, Secretary of the Veterans of the 7th Regiment, many of which discuss their recent activities, their service in the 7th, and include information about other 7th members. There are numerous V-Mails. Veterans of the 7th Regiment material also includes nineteenth-century orders, circulars, reports, and by-laws, and bulletins from the 1940s-1960s. Society of War Veterans and Veterans of the National Guard material includes records books, correspondence, minutes, circulars, and printed items. Two minute books of the Veterans Military Rifle Association of New York City are also found in this subseries.
See also Series IX for Veterans ephemera.

scopecontent.p: This subseries contains other material related to the regiment that does not fit into the above subseries. It includes press releases, documents regarding the regiment's bill of dress, emergency plans, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains material directly related to the companies of the 7th Regiment. Material includes rosters and roll books, orders, resolutions, by-laws, enlistment records, correspondence, memos, reports, financial records, circulars, record books, minutes, notices, and a few photographs. The bulk of the material is for companies B and F.

Major portions of this series include approximately two boxes of enlistment records, especially for Co. B, (1939-1949), which contain basic biographic information, and sometimes health information, for 7th members and potential members. Co. F. material includes the company's World War I files: orders, memos, bulletins, and schedules that discuss appointments, inspection instructions, health matters, marching and behavioral discipline, food, postal regulations, enforcement of attire regulations, and various procedures.

Note: the 7th Regiment initially designated companies by number, not letter. This practice continued even after the letter system was instituted; therefore, for example, Co. B and 2nd Company are the same. There is no Company J.

For other material relating to 7th Regiment companies, see rosters [c1942-1947] in the Veterans of the 7th Regiment files, Series I (Subseries 10). See also Series IX for ephemera (bulk Co. B), and Series XIV: Visual Materials for oversized items and photo albums relating to companies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials related to the Depot (Home) Battalion, 7th Infantry who defended the aqueduct in Pleasantville, New York during World War I in 1917. The materials summarize the duties of the men defending the aqueduct or relate to the Aqueduct Association, its veterans organization.

did.unittitle: Aqueduct Association--Materials re: Fifth and Sixth Annual Outings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Francis G. Landon (1859-1947) was a politician from New York City. He joined the 7th Regiment as a private, rose through the ranks and was promoted to Major. During the period ca.1912 to ca.1916, he was involved in the education of military officers, initially as a student, but later, apparently, as an instructor. Following the United States' declaration of war against Germany in 1917, Landon served as Morale Officer at Camp Merritt, NJ. This series consists of material that Landon accumulated primarily during these two stages of his career. The series is divided into three principal subseries. These are: General Correspondence, Military Education, and Camp Merritt, NJ.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The General Correspondence subseries consists of personal letters to Landon and his retained copies of his replies. Letters received by Landon are arranged chronologically in a folder titled General Correspondence - Letters Received. Landon's replies are arranged alphabetically, with one folder for each recipient of Landon's letters. The letters concern two subjects: the study of military history and a proposed program of rifle practice in colleges.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Material in the Military Education subseries consists primarily of small booklets of problem-solving exercises for military officers. These booklets were published by the Army Service Schools, where Landon attended classes during the academic year 1913 - 1914, and perhaps at other times. For purposes of the arrangement of this series, these booklets are referred to as Map Problems, the genre name applied to most of the booklets. In those instances that Landon kept a map with the booklet, they are housed together. Otherwise, maps are housed separately. Also included in this subseries are Landon's solutions to some of the Map Problems, evidently composed as course work, and some problems that appear to have been composed by Landon, perhaps for courses that he taught. This material is arranged according to the particular school that issued it, or, if no specific school is identified, the course to which it pertains. If no school or course is specified, the folder title indicates only the type of material found within it.

Landon appears to have taught at least one course in military tactics. Some material in the collection appears to be lecture notes or typewritten handouts that accompanied lectures. It some cases, it is unclear whether these notes and handouts are from lectures that Landon attended, or whether he composed them for lectures that he delivered. Some notes and typescripts pertaining to Landon's military education at Fort Leavenworth are identified as such.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Camp Merritt, NJ subseries contains, for the most part, material created by or relating to the Morale Office at that facility. A small portion of the material in the subseries concerns the Camp in general, and is not specific to the Morale Office. Included is correspondence to and from the Morale Office. Note that this folder group is distinct from the General Correspondence subseries, and includes material addressed to other offices on Camp Merritt, but routed to and answered by the Morale Office. Letters received by the Morale Office are arranged chronologically in a folder titled Morale Office - Letters Received. Retained copies of the Morale Office's replies are arranged in folders by the name of the letter's recipient. Subjects include: programs to maintain the morale of soldiers stationed at Camp Merritt (e.g. sporting events, Christmas decorations, 4th of July fireworks, etc.); commemorative medals for the schoolchildren of Bergen County, NJ, to be paid for by the personnel of the Camp; and weekly reports to the war Department on the state of the soldiers' morale.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains the World War II era files of Lt. Robert M. Lester, who served in the New York State Guard, Headquarters and Service Company. Topics include 7th Regiment history, training, the Second Service Command Tactical School, and Camp Smith. The bulk of the material is memoranda and administrative items. Lester's collection of photographs can be found in Series XIV: Visual Materials.

did.unittitle: New York Guard Association, Delegates to Convention

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of materials relating to the building and maintenance of the 7th Regiment armories. Most of the material relates to the armory on Park Avenue and 66th Street, built in 1880. For other information see the reports of the Armory Committee under Committees, Series I: Headquarters.

did.unittitle: Regulations of the National Guard Armory
Proposed Acts and Laws re: New Armory
List of "Work Done by the Regiment" on the Armory

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains various histories of the 7th Regiment, some of which are general regimental histories (primarily commemorative or promotional), and others histories or reminiscences of specific time periods, events, or designations of the regiment. The account of the Astor Place Riot is told from a man claiming to be both an instigator of the conflict and a member of 7th Regiment sent to suppress the riot.

"American 'National Guards,' A Brief Memoir... by Henry O'Reilly"

"Reminiscence of the Flour Riot in 1837" (2 copies)
"March of the 7th Regiment N.G.N.Y. to Washington" (typescript of 1861 sermon)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The scrapbooks in this collection contain various types of material including clippings, ephemera, photographs, correspondence, and cartoons. Some scrapbooks pertain to the regiment as a whole, other are scrapbooks of specific individuals, and some cover particular events or topics such as the regiment's centennial celebration, and the Croton Dam strike. Two scrapbooks from 1909 and 1912 document the 7th Regiment's participation in war games. The scrapbooks are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes primarily items related to 7th Regiment events, World War I, the 7th's Mexican border service, companies, and veterans. Material related to 7th Regiment events includes programs, tickets, announcements, and menus for various dinners, balls, excursions, celebrations, and concerts (1820-1964). World War I material contains instructional, promotional, and recruitment items from the Red Cross and other relief organizations, the armed services, the U.S. Food Administration, and various other sources. Ephemera related to the 7th's Mexican border service in 1916 is primarily newspaper clippings, also some New York State election material. Company ephemera mostly documents company events, such as dinners, parties, and entertainment. Veteran material is also mainly events related, especially annual dinners and reunions.

Other material in this series includes 7th Regiment and National Guard recruitment items; pamphlets, brochures, flyers, posters, and circulars from various sources; Civil War broadsides that advertise amusements; training material; divine service and memorial programs; various ads and catalogs; election nominee slips and calling cards; postcards; non-military or 7th Regiment certificates; and newspaper clippings.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Digital copies of selected ephemera are available in the Shelby White and Leon Levy Digital Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes primarily regimental sheet music, song books, and musical instruction, as well as administrative items for the Drum Corps and Band.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains material related to the Rifle Club and athletic activities of the 7th Regiment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bulk of Rifle Club material relates to the 7th Regiment's matches with the Queen's Westminster Volunteers in 1905 and 1906. This includes the files of Capt. B.B. McAlpin which contain telegrams, ephemera and clippings for the 1905 match in England. Also found in this subseries is a scrapbook for the 1906 match. Other Rifle Club material includes bulletins, correspondence, minutes, programs, record and score books. See Series XIV for a photo album of the 1905 Queen's Westminsters match.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Athletics material primarily consists of programs for the annual 7th Regiment Games. Also included are Athletic Association minutes and various programs, schedules and flyers relating to baseball, tennis, golf, and lacrosse events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The material in this series relate to the administration and collection of the 7th Regiment library. This includes catalog cards and lists of books and materials in the library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The publications series contains 7th Regiment and non-7th Regiment publications from the 7th Regiment Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains the publications and material regarding the business and printing of the publications of the 7th Regiment. The main publications of the 7th include the Seventh Regiment Gazette and the Seventh Regiment Guardsman. Most of the material in this subseries is either copies of the Seventh Regiment Gazette or publication material regarding the Gazette. Other publications include the Seventh Regiment Field Gazette, the Camp Worth Journal, and the Merritt Dispatch. The series also includes the mock-ups, photos, article submissions, and any correspondence having to do with publications. Newsletters for specific companies are located in Series II.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Digital copies of the Seventh Regiment Gazette are available in the Shelby White and Leon Levy Digital Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes photographs, etchings, illustrations from periodicals, lantern slides, color prints, posters, negatives, and one daguerreotype.

The bulk of photographs are individual portraits, company or other group portraits, scenes of activity in various camps (particularly Camp Smith in Peekskill, NY), marching units and parades, and interiors of the 7th Regiment Armory. There are portraits in albums and in boxes. Box 68 contains portraits of most all of the Regiment Colonels along with many others. This series also contains a number of Civil War portraits, both individual and group. The many camp photographs show members of the regiment involved in training activities of all kinds.

Notable events are represented throughout the series. Examples include photographs of the Brooklyn Trolley Strike in 1895 (Box 61, Fol. 1), a photograph of the ticker tape parade for Charles Lindbergh in 1927 (Box 71, Fol. 6), and a photograph album entitled "Thirty-three War Time 1861-3 Photographs."

Items of interest include color plates of military uniforms (1853-1858); French prints of charcoal and pencil sketches; "Life Studies of the Great Army" Etchings (1862-1865); and watercolor "Camp Sites at the Outbreak of the Civil War" (1862). A large extra illustrated volume completed in 1871 focuses on the 1861 participation of the 7th Regiment in the defense of Washington at the beginning of the Civil War.

There are more than 115 posters in this series. Most involve recruitment and solicitation of financial support for World War I and represent the United States and several European countries. There are also a few depicting Civil War battles.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Digital copies of photographs are available in the Shelby White and Leon Levy Digital Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: U.S.: War Stamps and Bonds, Liberty Loan, Red Cross, Recruitment Posters (Marines, Navy), United War Work Campaign (including one from the American Library Assn.), and posters to encourage businesses to hire returning soldiers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One of the posters is British, made from canvas, that 'advertises' the British Red Cross Society and the Order of St. John Enquiry Department for Wounded and Missing. All the rest are US, including War Bonds, Liberty Bonds, Red Cross, Army and Navy Recruitment. There are five poster 'portraits', dated 1918, from The New York Herald - Magazine of the War.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes European posters (German, French, British, Scottish) focusing on recruitment and solicitation. The remaining 31 posters are U.S., including six poster "portraits', dated 1918, from The New York Herald - Magazine of the War; Liberty Loan (including one from the Boy Scouts of America), Buy Bonds, Red Cross solicitations (including one Red Cross Christmas Roll Call), and American Field Service.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes maps used for military training and maneuvers in the U.S., and maps depicting European campaigns and events of World War I. Most of the maps are topographical and strategic; some training maps have markings, many of the World War I maps are labeled.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains artifacts of the 7th Regiment. It includes many ribbons, pins, and flags. It also includes other items such as dog tags, games, and a booklet on the project to catalog the items in the 7th Regiment library.
